newsitem.title: ISRAEL: Sacked musician begs Israel forgive Hitler "joke".
newsitem.headline: Sacked musician begs Israel forgive Hitler "joke".

text.p: A German musician said he could not explain why he signed a hotel bill "Adolf Hitler" while touring Israel and asked forgiveness for the incident that sparked a storm of protest.
The Berlin Opera company said on Monday it had sacked Gerd Reinke, a 54-year-old double bass player, over the incident at a Tel Aviv hotel bar in the early hours of Saturday.

"What I did is unbelievable. I myself still cannot comprehend it. Only 24 hours afterwards did I understand what I had caused," Reinke told the Israeli newspaper Maariv in an interview conducted in Germany and published on Tuesday.

"On Saturday morning I was still teaching music students at (an Israeli) kibbutz. I ask in every way possible for forgiveness and a pardon from all citizens of Israel and especially from my hosts in Israel. There is no limit to my regret and I am suffering more than anyone," he said.

Berlin Opera musicians still in Israel visited the Yad Vashem Holocaust Memorial in Jerusalem on Tuesday and laid a wreath there in the Hall of Remembrance for the six million Jews killed by Nazi Germany under Hitler in World War Two.
Opera officials, issuing hurried apologies for what they called an isolated incident, said the musician had been drinking heavily before he signed the bill.
But Germany's mass-circulation daily Bild newspaper, carrying the story on the front page, said Israeli journalists had shown he had only had two beers in the hotel bar.

Other German newspapers were equally unwilling to pass the affair off as a joke, with some suggesting it showed how deeply anti-Semitism ran in Germany and that it added fire to the debate over the role of ordinary Germans in the Holocaust.
